title: Maarten Gerritsz Vries
text:
Maarten Gerritszoon Vries, or Fries, also referred to as de Vries, (18 February 1589, <a href="Harlingen%2C%20Friesland">Harlingen</a>, <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a> – late 1647, at sea near <a href="Manila">Manila</a>) was a 17th-century Dutch <a href="cartographer">cartographer</a> and explorer, the first Western European to leave an account of his visit to <a href="Ezo">Ezo</a>, <a href="Sakhalin">Sakhalin</a>, <a href="Kuril%20Islands">Kuril Islands</a> and the <a href="Sea%20of%20Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a>.
Not much is known about the life of de Vries. He was probably born in <a href="Harlingen%2C%20Netherlands">Harlingen, Netherlands</a>, in 1589 and spent many years in <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>. He is best remembered for his 1643 expedition to the north-western <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> to discover the coast of <a href="Tartaria">Tartaria</a>, on account of <a href="Anthony%20van%20Diemen">Anthony van Diemen</a>, the governor in <a href="Batavia%2C%20Dutch%20East%20Indies">Batavia</a>. This was the second expedition to look for legendary gold and silver islands in the <a href="Pacific">Pacific</a>, which nobody had discovered, after a failed expedition in 1639 under command of <a href="Matthijs%20Quast">Matthijs Quast</a>.
De Vries expedition.
The two ships, the "<a href="Castricum">Castricum</a>" under De Vries and the "<a href="Breskens">Breskens</a>" under <a href="Hendrick%20Cornelisz%20Schaep">Hendrick Cornelisz Schaep</a> left <a href="Batavia%2C%20Dutch%20East%20Indies">Batavia</a>, the capital of Dutch <a href="Java">Java</a>, in February 1643. After a stop in <a href="Ternate">Ternate</a> in the <a href="Moluccas">Moluccas</a> they continued their journey on April 4. On May 20 the two ships lost touch with each other in a storm, while off <a href="Hachij%C5%8D-jima">Hachijo Shima</a>, an island some 290 km south of <a href="Edo">Edo</a>, which, due to this setback, was christened "Ongeluckich", or "Unlucky", Island by the Dutch.
"Breskens" in Yamada.
The "Breskens" arrived in a promising bay and was received friendly by the population of <a href="Yamada%2C%20Iwate">Yamada</a> on <a href="Tohoku">Tohoku</a>, <a href="Japan">Japan</a>. Six weeks later the "Breskens" again sailed to Yamada, probably while they had a good time. In the evening they organized a party with a <a href="samurai">samurai</a> and most probably some Japanese women. (It is not known what exactly happened, because the diary got lost in 1692, after <a href="Nicolaes%20Witsen">Nicolaes Witsen</a> received it.) The next day, July 29, ten members of the crew, including the captain were invited by the women to come to a farm where they would receive fresh vegetables and fish. The unarmed crew was offered <a href="sake">sake</a> and rice, but captured, and sent to <a href="Morioka">Morioka</a> and <a href="Edo">Edo</a> for <a href="interrogation">interrogation</a>. The Japanese feared Portuguese / Spanish <a href="Jesuits">Jesuits</a> had come to land. As a result, <a href="bakufu">bakufu</a> officials were extremely anxious about the problem of coastal defenses. However, after it was understood that the crew were Dutch <a href="merchants">merchants</a> and not Catholics, the problem to be solved became one of deciding by which procedure the Dutch should be released. After <a href="Jan%20van%20Elserac">Jan van Elserac</a> had arrived the "<a href="sh%C5%8Dgun">shōgun</a>" <a href="Tokugawa%20Iemitsu">Tokugawa Iemitsu</a> sent them in December to <a href="Deshima">Deshima</a>. The crew had to wait nine months for the next ship to <a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a> while the "Breskens" had left Honshu already at the end of July (without a captain) searching for the Gold and Silver Islands.
"Castricum" going north.
In the summer of 1643, the "Castricum" sailed by the southern <a href="Kuril%20Islands">Kuril Islands</a>, visiting <a href="Kunashir">Kunashir</a>, <a href="Iturup">Iturup</a> (which they named "Staten Island", although nowadays this name is only used to refer to <a href="Staten%20Island">Staten Island</a>, in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>), and <a href="Urup">Urup</a>, where they met with the <a href="Ainu%20people">Ainu</a>, and which they named "Company Island" and claimed for the Netherlands.
The "Castricum" passed between the islands of Iturup and Urup, the strait between the islands being later named <a href="Vries%20Strait">Vries Strait</a> after its discoverer, and entered the <a href="Sea%20of%20Okhotsk">Sea of Okhotsk</a>.
The Dutch sailed north, without encountering any land, until being driven south-west toward the northern shores of <a href="Hokkaido">Hokkaido</a>. Then they sailed north again, discovering <a href="Cape%20Aniva">Cape Aniva</a> (the southeastern tip of <a href="Sakhalin%20Island">Sakhalin Island</a>), <a href="Gulf%20of%20Patience">Gulf of Patience</a> (where they indeed had to be patient, waiting for the fog to clear), and <a href="Cape%20Patience">Cape Patience</a> east of it.
After another excursion, now east into the Pacific, the "Castricum" returned to Japanese waters and managed to meet with the "Breskens" off <a href="Kyushu">Kyushu</a>. The two ships sailed to <a href="Fort%20Zeelandia%20%28Taiwan%29">Fort Zeelandia (Taiwan)</a> and returned to Batavia in mid-December 1643.
Battles of La Naval de Manila.
Maarten Gerritsz Vries died on board from disease after leading an <a href="Battles%20of%20La%20Naval%20de%20Manila">unsuccessful attempt</a> to invade the Philippines.
